Tien and I tried to drive up to the place where we got married. We hadn't been there since that day, but in the time between then and now it was engulfed in the center of the Waldo Canyon Fire. We're interested to see what it looks like now. Unfortunately access to that area is still prohibited while the vegetation regrows.

entry.title: 35::182 - Vincent's 2nd day in USA
entry.summary:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

Tien's good friend and college classmate Vincent arrived in America yesterday and the head of a two year student visa and Fulbright Scholarship studying in West Virginia. He and the other Fulbright students are taking a month to study at the Monterey Institute of International Studies …
entry.content:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

Tien's good friend and college classmate Vincent arrived in America yesterday and the head of a two year student visa and Fulbright Scholarship studying in West Virginia. He and the other Fulbright students are taking a month to study at the Monterey Institute of International Studies in Pacific Grove before heading on to their collegiate destinations. Tien and I took our third anniversary trip down to Monterey to coincide with his arrival, welcome him and see some sights together. Here they are at the Bixby Bridge.

Today I got off work a bit late and found that the L train wasn't coming for 15 minutes. I caught the N and took it all the way to the beach. When I got off I found a beautiful sunset. With music in my ears and my camera in my hand I strolled along the path, enjoying the scene, and I found that I was not the only one.

entry.content:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

This man and his little entourage frequently stand at Powell Station by the cable car turntable and shout loudly at people about how we're all going to burn in hell. He and his crew try to coerce people to join their religious sect by vocal intimidate, taunting and condemning. I've never seen anybody say anything nice to him, and am curious if he's ever brought somebody to Jesus with his tactics.

entry.title: 35::137 - Tien in dim light
entry.content:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

I'm amazed at the VR performance of the 70-200mm VR ii. You can shoot it hand-held at 1/(focal length/10), blowing away the traditional hand-held rule. This shot is 200mm @ 1/20s hand-held, and I can't see any motion blur when zoomed 1:1.

WarzauWynn posted a photo:

entry.title: 35::132 - Pinhole of a prism
entry.summary:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

A long time ago I took a Nikon body cap an drilled a big hole in it with a dremel tool. Then I cut open an aluminum can and taped part of it over the hole. Then i poked a hole in it with a sewing …
entry.content:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

A long time ago I took a Nikon body cap an drilled a big hole in it with a dremel tool. Then I cut open an aluminum can and taped part of it over the hole. Then i poked a hole in it with a sewing needle. This created a very tiny aperture. This is how you make a pinhole camera. The aperture was too small though, not enough light was coming through, and you could tell it wasn't circular. Finding something only slightly larger than a sewing needle was difficult, so today I decided to just push a thumb tack through it. This created a very nice round hole, but it was too large to make a very clear image. In any case, this is a photo I took using a piece of an aluminum can as a lens on my D800. Maybe next I'll dry tin foil, that's supposed to work well.

entry.title: 35::123 - Nate at Rickhouse
entry.summary:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

Tonight I got together with my friend Nathan for the first time in forever. We passed through Rickhouse on our way around downtown and had a sip of Ardbeg Corryvreckan. I hadn't been to Rickhouse since I had my D3s, so it was interesting to see …
entry.content:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

Tonight I got together with my friend Nathan for the first time in forever. We passed through Rickhouse on our way around downtown and had a sip of Ardbeg Corryvreckan. I hadn't been to Rickhouse since I had my D3s, so it was interesting to see how well the low light performance of the D800 compared. I think it did spectacularly, and although I really love the D3s, I gotta say I think the D800 is better overall.

entry.summary:

I'd been throwing around the idea of picking up a f/1.2 lens, but the thought of having another MF lens wasn't all that awesome. My friend Dan picked up the Canon 50mm f/1.2L AF and after looking at how great the images …
entry.content:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

I'd been throwing around the idea of picking up a f/1.2 lens, but the thought of having another MF lens wasn't all that awesome. My friend Dan picked up the Canon 50mm f/1.2L AF and after looking at how great the images were I thought I'd finally pick one up, so I found this pre-AI Nikkor 55mm f/1.2 S•C on CL. It just barely fits on my D800, but I'll have to have it converted in order for it to function well. It's too bad that Canon is the only manufacturer who makes f/1.2 AF lenses.

WarzauWynn posted a photo:

I posted this in full resolution because the tiny details are interesting.

entry.content:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

The wind blew a bunch of sand onto the highway a week or so ago, so the highway has been closed down since then. The weather has been good and they finally came and cleaned the sand off, but for some reason the highway is still closed. It's nice for the pedestrians, but but the drivers take out their frustrations by driving faster than they should in a long line down our residential street.

entry.title: 35::59 - Tien at the Stockton crossroads
entry.summary:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

I picked up this Nikkor 28mm ƒ/2.8D lens off Craigslist today for $150 and went straight out to take pleasing photos with it. I was really happy to find an AF wide prime for a decent price. I'm a little bummed that Nikon hasn't …
entry.content:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

I picked up this Nikkor 28mm ƒ/2.8D lens off Craigslist today for $150 and went straight out to take pleasing photos with it. I was really happy to find an AF wide prime for a decent price. I'm a little bummed that Nikon hasn't made any cheap AF-S wide primes, their only offerings cost many hundreds of dollars and are large, heavy things. That's one reason I've been shooting the 35mm DX on my D800 so often, but now I have this even wider FX so that's rad.

entry.title: 35::55 - Infinity Bliss
entry.summary:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

The D800 has an in-cam multiple exposure feature. You can do anywhere from two to ten exposures with the same settings. This photo was taken with three exposures at 1 second each. For the first two I focused on the Infinity Towers, then took the camera …
entry.content:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

The D800 has an in-cam multiple exposure feature. You can do anywhere from two to ten exposures with the same settings. This photo was taken with three exposures at 1 second each. For the first two I focused on the Infinity Towers, then took the camera and moved it sinuously upwards. The third exposure is a stationary, defocused shot of the Infinities.

After two years of not owning a car Tien and I felt it was time to get back on the road. She has a goal of learning how to drive a car this year, and I am ready to start exploring more of California and resume getting out of the city on the weekends. The used car scene on CL has been brutal lately, so we caved and went to a used car dealer that had this 2003 Corolla in really good shape.

entry.title: 35::28 - D5200
entry.summary:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

I got my D800 back today after having it repaired for drop damage that caused it to back-focus. I took this test shot of the D5200 I've been happy with while the D800 was in the shop and was pleased to see it's back to sharp …
entry.content:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

I got my D800 back today after having it repaired for drop damage that caused it to back-focus. I took this test shot of the D5200 I've been happy with while the D800 was in the shop and was pleased to see it's back to sharp focus.

D5200 is a really great camera. I highly recommend it for people who want an SLR without going too high on price.

I put some video of the Bay Lights on Youtube.

entry.summary:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

There's a speed boat behind that wave, but you can't see it because the wave is so large.

I got my D5200 today and this was one of the 19th photo I took with it. I'm already enjoying it as much as any other camera with …
entry.content:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

There's a speed boat behind that wave, but you can't see it because the wave is so large.

I got my D5200 today and this was one of the 19th photo I took with it. I'm already enjoying it as much as any other camera with the flip-out LCD form factor, but it has a feature I've long wanted and never seen on any camera I've owned: an option to automatically set the minimum shutter speed based on focal length when shooting with auto-ISO. This feature was available in the T3i, but at the expense of manual minimum shutter speed selection. The D5200 has both, and that is a beautiful thing. (I later found that the D800 also has this feature but I'd missed it.) This image was taken with that feature enabled. The camera wouldn't let the shutter time go below 1/500s with such a long zoom on a cropped sensor, so it upped the ISO to 250 to keep the shutter time fast. I didn't have to choose 1/500s, the camera selected that based on my focal length.

On the down side, Nikon really needs to implement focus peaking like the Sony NEX has. Live-view benefits so much from focus peaking, especially with the flip out screen where you're doing weird angles and need visual feedback of precise focus, eg: ground-level macros. They should be doing everything they can to get whatever legal rights they need to get in order to have that feature.

WarzauWynn posted a photo:

My grandmother passed away this morning. She was an amazing woman who lived a long, full life.

entry.summary:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

I'm 35 today. This is the beginning of my fourth 365 project.

If you're considering starting a 365 project, do it. It is very personally satisfying and much easier than writing in a journal. I treat mine as a documentary so there is no pressure to …
entry.content:
WarzauWynn posted a photo:

I'm 35 today. This is the beginning of my fourth 365 project.

If you're considering starting a 365 project, do it. It is very personally satisfying and much easier than writing in a journal. I treat mine as a documentary so there is no pressure to be creative on days when I am in a funk. I wish I had started years earlier.
